Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Carbon-Nanotube-Coated Copper Wires for High Frequency Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this collaborative research project is to address the grand challenge caused by the skin and proximity effects in high-frequency applications. The objective of this project is to develop copper wires coated with copper-decorated carbon nanotubes to achieve reduced energy loss and overheating in electrical and electronic devices. The research approaches include realization of copper-decorated carbon nanotubes on textured copper wires to reduce the inter-tube impedance of carbon-nanotube films, uniformly aligning carbon nanotubes on copper wires using a simple mechanical wiping method, understanding the mechanism of reduced skin and proximity effects in carbon-nanotube-coated copper wires, and reducing the energy loss and overheating using the carbon-nanotube-coated copper wires.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to significant outcomes, including controllable, aligned coating of carbon nanotubes on copper wires, fabricating robust CNT films through mechanical wiping, and carbon-nanotube-coated copper wires of high electrical and thermal conductivities for high-frequency applications. This research will impact all societal levels by revolutionizing the performance of copper wires in a wide range of applications. Practically, the proposed method is expected to provide a novel approach to reduce energy loss and heat generation in high-frequency applications. The research results will also contribute to productivity improvement, energy savings, and environmental protection in related industries that rely on high-frequency electrical signals and powers. Graduate and undergraduate students will benefit through involvement in the research and classroom instruction. The engagement of K-12 students and teachers in this project will also establish new partnerships between the universities and K-12 schools.

Institution.Name: University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

(Award Number–1265122) 

Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) possess extraordinary properties that make them promising candidates for improving the performance in a wide range of industrial applications. The saturated skin depth and long mean free path in these one-dimensional super materials make them a potential solution to the long-standing limitation of the Eddy-current-induced power loss in metallic conductors in high-frequency applications. However, practical realization of these properties and the integration of CNTs through conventional fabrication methods has proven to be challenging in terms of quality control, reproducibility, and cost-effectiveness. Therefore, there is extensive interest in addressing these challenges through the development and implementation of scalable, cost-effective processing approaches for the integration of CNTs into industrial applications.

Researchers at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL) developed a fast, simple, and cost-effective approach to coating and implementing multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) on metallic conductors of various sizes and geometrical configurations. Successful suppression of ac resistance of up to 94% was realized in MWCNT-coated copper (MWCNT-Cu) planar conductors at high operational frequencies (0-15 MHz) through electrophoretic deposition followed by infrared laser treatment of MWCNT coatings on copper (Cu). The resistance reduction was observed to be proportional to the laser irradiation power density below the MWCNT film breakdown threshold. At 10 MHz, a maximum AC resistance reduction of 94% was observed in a MWCNT-Cu conductor after being irradiated at a laser power density of 189 W/cm2. The AC resistance reduction and skin effect suppression were ascribed to the implementation of MWCNTs, which provide low-resistance current channels insensitive to frequency changes.

Additional roles of laser irradiation were found to be vital in densifying MWCNTs, reducing tube-to-tube contact resistance, and removing impurities in MWCNTs, which are beneficial in forming densely packed MWCNT films and reducing resistance. In addition, uniform, dense, and highly conductive MWCNT layers were fabricated on the surface of Cu coils in order to suppress the copper loss in MHz wireless power transfer (WPT) systems, where MWCNTs performed as an alternative frequency-independent electrical channel, leading to the suppression of the skin effect in Cu coils. A fourfold increase was achieved in the quality factor of the MWCNT-Cu coils (at f =15 MHz). The high aspect ratio and the large surface area of the MWCNT coating was proven to play an important role in the reflection of the external electromagnetic field induced by the current flowing in the adjacent turns, thereby leading to mitigation of the proximity effect. When MWCNT-Cu coils were used as the transmitter components in the WPT system, efficiencies as high as 95.81% were realized at f = 3.45 MHz. The proposed method was effective at increasing the available load resistance and transmission range. The improvements achieved in this work were directly related to the inductance value of the coils, indicating the potential of MWCNT coatings to improve the performance of WPT systems.

By combining the CNT deposition techniques with the ultrafast laser drilling methods, an effective and cost-efficient method was proposed and developed to suppress the destructive arcing that occurs on the rails in a third rail system and damages their surfaces. The superior electrical conductivity and superior field emission properties of MWCNTs were used to divide and distribute the arcing current density into small and harmless portions through laser drilling of a grid of microholes on the surface of rails followed by implanting of these holes with MWCNTs, leading to the formation of a highly conductive composite. The MWCNT-implanted rails were observed to be significantly less damaged after the arcing experiment.

Under this NSF award, one graduate student and two undergraduate students received systematic multidisciplinary training on electrochemical processing of CNTs, material characterization, optical spectroscopic analysis, and laser processing during the project period. Multidisciplinary knowledge established in this project was distributed via teaching (ELEC 973, Introduction to Nanotechnology), undergraduate research experience programs, journal publications (three), conference presentations (two), external collaboration, and outreach activities. Due to the value of the research and potential applications, the Nebraska team is seeking collaboration with government agencies and industry. As one of the few CNT research groups in the U.S.A., the Nebraska team demonstrated leadership in this field.

 


Last Modified: 08/07/2018
Modified by: Yongfeng Lu
